Engages quietly and thoughtfully when the young man reveals his connection to Julia.
Expresses disappointment and a sense of personal hurt that Pratt’s father never answered her letter and did not contact her before he died.
Appears bored and detached from the party initially, standing alone and silent.
Pressures Pratt aggressively about Julia's family and the baby, showing suspicion and hostility
Softly controlling her rage and managing her emotions despite provocation

Is aware of the dreary, lifeless atmosphere but stays composed and attentive.
Nods uncertainly at the grandparents and shows hesitation in how to behave, indicating some social discomfort or lack of confidence.

Whispers a comment about the photograph and expresses surprise, demonstrating observational awareness and engagement.
Follows Julia's lead through the social situation without initiating interaction or conversation herself.
Looks out the window, surveys work on her table, then leaves the room without obvious decision or visible action.
Moves slowly up the stairs, pensive and uncertain; expresses doubt aloud about her work and contemplates whether she might do better elsewhere.
Engages tenderly with Hammett, showing emotional intelligence and interpersonal sensitivity.

Expresses ongoing dedication to her writing career despite working at a publishing house instead of full-time writing, shows confidence in Julia's abilities and plans, engages in thoughtful conversation about ambitions and studies.
Shows uncertainty about personal romantic life ('I'm not sure. I think maybe I've met someone.') which indicates some lack of confidence or decisiveness in personal matters.
Asks if Julia can understand Einstein, indicating curiosity and willingness to engage intellectually, but not showing clear mastery herself.

Admits she didn’t fully understand the gravity of the political situation or her friend Julia’s warnings.
Moves cautiously through a dangerous environment, observes events carefully, attempts to maintain communication on the phone despite interruptions.
Feels sick and frightened, struggles to concentrate on her work amid chaos.
Stops to watch from a distance the developing violent situation before deciding to retreat to safety.

Persistently questions the nurse despite language barriers and attempts to avoid giving information, refusing to leave without answers about the operation.

Waits patiently in the corridor, even while weary, showing concern by following the nurse and staying near Julia.
Responds attentively to Julia's gestures and tries to understand her despite the difficulty in communication.

Moves quickly and cautiously along the sidewalk, remaining vigilant and aware of her surroundings.
Confronts the young boy who gives her a note, trying to get information from him.
Completes her manuscript, types 'THE END' repeatedly, showing determination and focus on finishing her work.
Leaves the beach house quietly, carefully closing the door so it won't bang, showing mindfulness and control.
Waits patiently and contemplatively when talking with Hammett, demonstrating emotional control and reflective listening.
Struggles with the quality of her writing as indicated by Hammett’s critique but continues to work with intensity, showing perseverance.

Expresses frustration and vulnerability when Hammett refuses to go to Russia with her.
Explodes in anger about fear and wanting to go alone, showing emotional sincerity.
Urgently tries to get a message to Julia despite interruptions, showing care and persistence.

At the German consulate, sitting stiffly and responding with an impulse decision to change plans, showing some lack of preparation or strategic thinking about travel and visa regulations.

Acknowledges feeling unwell and tries to excuse herself politely before leaving the car.
Turns away from the Heavy Girl without further interaction after being watched carefully.
Avoids confrontation when two men with menacing looks approach, presses against the washroom door to stay safe.
Responds briefly and politely to the Thin Girl’s concerned question about her wellbeing.
Does not engage further with the Thin Girl and sits quietly rubbing her sore knee, showing little openness.
Sits quietly, rubs her sore knee, declines offered food politely despite discomfort.
Looks through the compartment door window into the corridor, appears alert to surroundings on the train.
Maintains calm and polite conversation when asked about her condition and shows awareness of others around her.
Body language betrays growing panic as train approaches border, indicating internal anxiety despite outward composure.
Reflects on past with Julia, describing herself as less graceful and struggling to keep up, but laughing and impressed by Julia’s strength.
Softly confesses love to Julia, initiates intimate and tender physical contact by holding hands and touching cheeks, lying close beside her.
Shows polite gratitude and compliance to advice from the girls about coat and hat despite fear.
In her growing panic, interacts respectfully with companions and does not cause trouble.
Hesitates briefly before following others, showing awareness and trust but some cautiousness.
Demonstrates presence of mind by responding appropriately to instructions about passport and clothing despite growing panic and confusion.
Hesitates momentarily when deciding to follow the Heavy Girl and Thin Girl after putting on coat and hat, showing some uncertainty.
Senses suspicious behavior in the Thin Girl who intentionally positions herself behind her in line, indicating alertness and perceptiveness.
Responds calmly and politely to border police questions, providing straightforward answers without defensiveness.
Maintains composure under scrutiny, engaging in normal conversation about travel plans and occupation.
Waits calmly and answers border police questions honestly but tactfully, providing plausible explanations without over-sharing.
Does not appear flustered or confused during the border check despite potential suspicion, maintaining composure.
Smiles charmingly and re-enters the train after hesitating.
Politely but firmly asks the Thin Girl not to open the candy box because it is a gift for a friend.
Does not assertively stop the Thin Girl from taking candy, who then opens the box anyway.
Recognizes suspicious eyes on her, hesitates briefly, but then re-enters the train showing situational awareness and caution.
Firmly stops the Thin Girl from opening the candy box, protecting a gift and showing protective control over her belongings.
Allows the Thin Girl to take candy despite her earlier warning, which leads to potential compromise by customs inspection.
Watches the Thin Girl carefully as she reties the ribbon on the candy box, sharing a quiet moment without speaking.
Returns the Heavy Girl's stare, maintaining connection amid tension.
Puts out her cigarette when Heavy Girl starts coughing, showing concern and sensitivity.
Remains tense and silent throughout the train journey, not initiating conversation or offering comfort despite visible tension.
Sits quietly and watches attentively without interrupting during tense moments on the train, showing calmness and readiness.
Lights a cigarette even when the other character is coughing strongly, then promptly puts it out, indicating awareness and some consideration.
Displays tense and alert body language, sitting straight and ready, indicating mental preparedness and focus.
Does not speak or initiate conversation in a moment of tension, possibly suggesting caution or restraint rather than passivity.
Looks anxious and tense while navigating a crowded, tense environment with two girls, staying composed and carrying their belongings carefully.
Maintains close proximity and moves together with the two girls she is escorting, suggesting protectiveness and responsibility.
Appears claustrophobic and uneasy, yet continues forward calmly, indicating steadiness under pressure.
No overt expression of friendliness or verbal kindness in this excerpt, largely non-verbal and internal anxiety.
Expresses gladness to see the woman again and embraces her, bringing small gifts.
Pauses with growing anxiety before entering the side entrance, takes deep breaths and proceeds cautiously.
Follows detailed instructions from the man carefully despite feeling growing anxiety, takes deep breaths to compose herself before proceeding through the gate and across the street.
Appears anxious and hesitant before executing the task, needing to pause and steady herself.
Approaches Julia slowly and anxiously, notices Julia's crutches and is moved to tears, sits silently beside her holding her hand.
Unable to speak immediately, chooses to stay quietly supportive in a difficult moment.
Moves slowly and anxiously, hesitates before entering the restaurant, appears frozen and unable to speak when confronted with Julia's condition.
Waits patiently for her turn to enter through the revolving door despite difficulty with her belongings.
Eventually sits next to Julia and communicates nonverbally, showing emotional sensitivity and care even when words fail.
Expresses distress and attempts to avoid hearing about Julia's injury but apologizes sincerely.
Listens attentively and follows Julia's instructions despite discomfort, showing trust and cooperation.
Attempts to maintain normalcy and good social behavior (removes hat, makes conversation) under stressful circumstances.
Reassures Julia by responding to her pride in her play; shows willingness to share personal professional doubts.
Offers to accompany Julia to the toilet and tries to help her with crutches.
Tries to laugh when Julia encourages acting gay, indicating openness and friendliness.
Politely thanks Albert (in German) for the caviar and wine.
Does not appear dismissive or impatient with Julia despite her disabilities and quirks.
Asks if she should come into the washroom with Julia, showing concern and attentiveness.
Waits outside the toilet door for Julia, looks around at other people, seems alert but patient.
Engages in light-hearted conversation with the waiter and Julia, sharing a laugh.
Is present and supportive while Julia speaks about the importance of saving lives, showing concern.
Shares a picture of Hammett willingly and speaks warmly about him to Julia.
Responds supportively and encourages Julia to visit soon despite difficult topics.
Is stunned by Julia's revelation about having a baby but does not reject or dismiss her.
Is visibly moved, close to tears when hearing about Julia's baby, showing emotional sensitivity.
Promises to take care of Julia's baby and expresses trustworthiness.
Says she doesn’t care about money, emphasizing sincerity and prioritizing care over material concerns.
Reluctantly follows Julia's urgent instructions despite visible upset and desire to stay longer.
Expresses care for Lily by promising to make it wonderful once she has room.
Shows quiet rage and frustration at the difficult situation.
Hesitates and struggles emotionally to say goodbye, indicating sincere attachment and care.
Struggles with accepting urgent instructions but ultimately complies (puts on the hat) despite personal reluctance and emotional difficulty.
Expresses emotional vulnerability and hesitation about leaving Julia and embarking on a risky journey with limited information and preparation.
Tries to reassure Julia by promising to take care and make it wonderful for Lilly, showing intention to manage responsibilities ahead.
Stops and takes a small step toward Julia after being told to leave, indicating hesitation and concern.
Turns and moves out through the door after Julia refuses her gesture.
Looks both ways on the street carefully, showing caution but also vulnerability.
Allows a man to take her arm and guides her to safety across a dangerous street.
Exchanges polite and warm farewells with the man at the train station and calls back 'My very best to you.'
Complies cooperatively with the conductor's instructions about luggage and border crossing without complaint.
Looks at the conductor with attention and concern before entering her compartment, showing engagement and responsiveness.
Remains silent and reflective upon hearing harsh voices recounting painful memories, suggesting internal sensitivity and empathy.
Sits politely when interacting with Sammy despite his drunkenness and loud behavior.
Warns Sammy not to continue with Napoleon, suggesting alternative subjects.
Avoids discussing marriage and abruptly ends conversation with Sammy.
Dismisses Sammy's teasing about marriage and drinking too much.
Refuses to tolerate attacks on Julia's beliefs or life from Sammy or Anne Marie.
Gets up and says goodbye to Sammy to end the uneasy conversation.
Interrupts and ends conversation with Sammy decisively when it becomes unproductive or uncomfortable.
Advises Sammy to abandon a project she perceives as futile or problematic (Napoleon book) and suggests a more manageable alternative.
Rejects inappropriate or distracting topics (marriage proposals from Sammy) confidently and firmly.
Refuses to tolerate negative talk about Julia, setting clear boundaries about whose opinions she accepts.
Avoids engaging deeply with emotionally charged or complicated family dynamics, possibly indicating detachment or emotional distancing.
Slaps Sammy quickly and pushes the table over on him after his crude remark.
Responds to a polite farewell from the young man in the train compartment, calmly notices the situation with her trunk and remains composed.
Responds instantly and decisively by slapping Sammy and pushing the table over on top of him when provoked.
Demonstrates alertness by waking up promptly and responding to the knocking at the train compartment door.
Does not reveal any uncertainty or hesitation when confronted with the young man's warning about her trunk and the German suspicion.
Sits deep in thought by the window, absorbing a foreign language performance and maintaining composure despite apparent boredom.
Shows signs of boredom, stifles a yawn during an important official event.
Responds quietly and somberly to Julia's death, appears thoughtful and restrained.
Shares a playful and imaginative moment with young Julia, laughing together on the hillside.
Shows visible pain and distress upon discovering the vandalized trunk.
Sharply refuses to look at the damaged remains, indicating a protective or sensitive response.
Reads the condolence note left by the undertaker, absorbing the sorrow communicated about her lost friend.
Moves quietly and somberly through the funeral parlor, allowing space for grief.
Kneels to open the trunk despite emotional pain, confronts the devastation of the ransacked belongings.
Sharp refusal to view the body parts at the funeral parlor, controlling the situation by setting boundaries with the undertaker.
Receives and processes the grim news with somber composure, preparing mentally to take action despite grief.
Moves fearfully toward the open casket, shows hesitation, then gently touches the deceased's face with her fingertips, displaying tenderness.

Attempts to follow up on a lead to find John Watson by persistently asking the undertaker and visiting a London address despite being given no helpful information, showing sincere concern and dedication.
Identifies herself as a friend of Julia to a stranger at the door while searching for John Watson, showing trust and openness.
Approaches the open casket carefully, shows emotional restraint instead of acting impulsively.
Persistently questions the undertaker about John Watson and the body despite lack of clear information.
Goes to an address given without verifying its accuracy beforehand, leading to a dead end.
Tries to gain information by speaking directly to a resident at the address, showing proactive behavior.
Does not immediately give up despite being told the address is wrong, showing determination.
Insists on pursuing information despite unclear leads and hostile responses, attempts to use a letter as proof to gain trust.
Pushes the door on someone denying correct information and persists even without clear direction on what she is looking for.
Struggles alone in a foreign place, appears distraught and somewhat confused by local details and geography (e.g., misunderstanding Alsace as a village).
Turns and looks frightened and confused, calls out to Mr Johann urgently.
Sits up perspiring from a nightmare; Hammett comforts her gently and she accepts consolation.
Speaks about Julia’s ashes with concern for Julia’s granddaughter, questioning if they care about the baby.
Pushes past the maid into Julia's grandparents’ house despite their objections, insisting she won't wait outside.
Runs through the station wearing a hat, calling out to Mr. Johann, indicating urgency and purposeful movement.
Sits up quickly from a nightmare, perspires, but follows husband's gentle advice and lies back down, showing self-regulation.
Holds Julia's ashes and questions what to do, expressing concern about the grandmother's neglect of the baby, reflecting emotional turmoil but also thoughtful reflection.
Refuses to wait outside when denied entry by the maid and pushes past her into the house to confront the situation directly.
Attempts to remind the butler of her childhood connection to Julia to gain entry, though the butler denies recognition.
Firmly refuses to leave until she speaks to Julia's grandparents, insists on handling Julia's ashes herself, challenges Raines' dismissive attitude.
Appeals to Raines' sense of humanity by reminding him Julia was the only one who treated him as a human being, showing emotional intelligence and tactical persuasion.
Experiences an attempted assault and tries to scream and escape.
Reaches desperately for the crying baby in the German woman's arms, merging her own screams with the baby's.
Breaks down crying privately after reflecting on not trying hard enough to save the baby.
Expresses anger toward those who exploited Julia's money, using the term 'The bastards.'
Refuses to accept bad news easily, persists in hope despite being told the baby is dead.
Insists on there being a trial and demands justice for Julia despite acknowledging the difficulty.
